snippet: Heavily armed fighters who seized a desert complex on Jan. 16 sought to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a bomb. What none of them knew was how, in the vast maze of metal, to do it.
abstract: Goal of heavily armed militants who seized desert gas plant in Algeria was to turn site into giant bomb, but none of assailants knew how to do it; detailed accounts from captives are offering more complete view of four-day standoff and hostage drama.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and NICHOLAS KULISH
byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from Tiguentourine, and Nicholas Kulish from Berlin. Reporting was contributed by Clifford Krauss from Houston; Henrik Pryser Libell from Oslo; Martin Fackler and Makiko Inoue from Tokyo; Stanley Reed, Lark Turner and John F. Burns from London; and Ravi Somaiya from New York.

lead_paragraph: Heavily armed fighters who seized a desert complex on Jan. 16 sought to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a bomb. What none of them knew was how, in the vast maze of metal, to do it.

headline.seo: Hostage Accounts Detail Events at Saharan Gas Plant
headline.main: Militants’ Goal in Algeria Gas Plant Siege: Giant Fireball
headline.print_headline: Militants’ Goal In Algeria Siege: A Giant Fireball
